In your career, you may be called upon to investigate incidents
with varying degrees of frequency and intensity. However, what do we specifically mean by ‘incident
CSA Z1005 Incident Investigation and Prevention Standard
an occurrence, condition or situation arising in the course of work that resulted in, or could have resulted in, injuries, illnesses, damage to health, or fatalities.
In broad terms, we refer to an
or possibly result in a loss for
n incident as an unplanned event that disrupts the orderly flow of the work process and results
in some form of consequence. For example, an oil refinery explosion (unplanned event) results in fatalities and property damage (consequences).
Standard Half Vertical with Image template
Man lying on floor after a fall
Injured person lying on the floor after slipping.
(Only used if VO doesn’t match onscreen text)
There are several reasons to investigate incidents. Mainly,
incident investigation is a part of
a hazard recognition, assessment, and control (RAC) program
. Beyond these reasons, incident investigations also benefit organizations in the following ways:
revent similar incidents from recurring in the future
a permanent record of the findings
Incident investigations depend upon the collection of
information collected during the course of an investigation for reference or analysis.
Data can be in the form of documents, records, statements, interviews, pictures, videos, materials, equipment, tools, information, statistics, etc.
discovery of non-incident related data that, although not directly related to the incident, could potentially pose a hazard or identify a deficiency.

, investigations may be guided by the following overarching principles:
A workplace incident investigation program exceeds the legislated incident investigation minimum investigation requirements in many jurisdictions
A well-planned incident investigation provides a company the greatest opportunity for improvement when it is used as a tool for prevention
nvestigators should rely on a solid understanding of risk assessment principles early in the
, rather than use incident investigation to solve issues afterward
utilize a safety management systems approach to identify and determine the influence of the workplace system on the occurrence of the incident
include worker participation as essential to the success of incide
present findings and recommendations as an opportunity to improve practices and processes

The broad definition of ‘incident’ includes different elements in the context of health and safety. Which of the following would be considered an ‘incident’ using this definition? Select All That Apply.
Lung disease caused by unfiltered exhaust pipes.
A ladder damages the entryway into a storage room.
A piece of machinery kills a worker.
An employee’s wallet is misplaced or stolen.
An employee avoids slipping on a spill

investigation system to ensure that the organization can learn as much as possible about contributing factors for every loss they experience.

Investigations can help organizations directly, but can also provide value in indirect ways. Here are some ways that organizations gain value from investigations:
all stakeholders in the organization are made aware of how underlying systems contributed to a loss
are usually motivated to explore how similar underlying factors may be impacting operations in their areas
or damage also contribute to sub-standard work quality and process interruptions
y identifying system problems through structured investigations and making concrete recommendations, organizations can make improvements to their systemic operations, and,
improve the quality and reliability of the products or services the organization provides
By carefully examining underlying factors related to a loss,
you can highlight workplace or equipment design features that
often resulting in clear recommendations for improvement without a complete re-design.
In the event of a major loss, a well-conducted investigation provides credible and timely information to the public and signals a proactive and responsive management group
. Companies gain a positive reputation when nearby communities can challenge or support the company’s health and safety performance.
In most jurisdictions, there is some level of incident investigation required
proactive company has a well-designed OSH&E investigation system that will meet or exceed regulatory requirements
If the regulators see a genuinely proactive investigation approach
any companies present their investigations to demonstrate their commitment to health and safety
may prevent the need for a compliance investigation, potential fines
often an underlying factor in incidents
A careful investigation will often reveal the nature of operating errors and strongly suggest corrective actions
Trust and mutual respect are the basis of healthy labour/management relations
comprehensive and credible incident investigation system
is often a fundamental part of building and maintaining trust and mutual respect
Facilitate Cultural Change Within the Organization
safety is a powerful primary human motivator
organization that actively demonstrates responsiveness and accountability for
workplace systems can reasonably expect to start shifting towards a relational, high trust culture where all stakeholders collaborate on developing and achieving corporate goals
good investigation promotes a collaborative workplace culture, increases safety awareness
in which issues are addressed both proactively and reactively by the company
change promotes the internal responsibility system of workers, supervisors

Was the work being performed according to procedures?

Herbert Heinrich created the domino theory in 1929 and expanded it over the years. The basis of this model is that incidents result from
a chain of sequential events, metaphorically
like a line of dominoes falling over
one of the dominoes falls, it triggers the next one, and
removing a key factor (such as an unsafe condition or an unsafe act) interrupts the completion
unsafe performance of persons, such as standing under suspended loads ... horseplay, and removal of safeguards
mechanical or physical hazards such as unguarded gears ... and insufficient light.
led with accident causes. They are

w:r.w:t: Five Metaphorical Dominoes of the Domino Theory.“

develop from a person’s social environment

atural or environmental flaws in the worker’s family or life cause these secondary personal defects

Another approach might be a description of the incident followed by a list of unsafe acts and conditions, followed by a work order for repair or cleanup, and direction to the worker to be more diligent.
the belief that unsafe acts are the primary cause of incidents

If the organization and the investigator have this view, they may bias the investigation toward listing or categorizing the basic causes as unsafe acts.
Examples of Unsafe Acts and Unsafe Conditions:
Operating or working at unsafe speed
Performing highly repetitive tasks and not taking breaks.
Using unsafe equipment, or using equipment unsafely
Disregarding appropriate working or safety procedures.
Working on moving or dangerous equipment
Failure to use safe attire or PPE
Inadequately ventilated, impure air source, etc
Unsafe processes: mechanical, chemical, electrical, nuclear

A major problem with this theory is that it is dated. The
original theory presupposes that workers are lazy, stupid, and
assumes single causes for incidents, strict sequences of events that work on one line of causation only

reflect the realities of a workplace

Reason’s update to the HFM became the basis for the Swiss Cheese Model.
The four levels of human error are arranged in order and

The benefit of this model is that it identifies failures at multiple levels and that solutions can focus on specific areas of prevention. It also recognizes that incidents do not occur in isolation, but are due to a variety of factors including different levels of supervision and accountability and organizational culture.
wo approaches to the problem of human fallibility exist
The person approach focuses on the errors of individuals, blaming them for forgetfulness, inattention, or moral weakness
The system approach concentrates on the conditions under which individuals work and tries to build defen
es to avert errors or mitigate their effects
adverse events involve a combination of these two factors.

within the system. They arise from decisions made by designers, builders, procedure writers

hey can create long-lasting holes or weaknesses in the defen

may lie dormant within the system for many years before they combine with active failures and local triggers to create an accident opportunity. Unlike active failures, whose specific forms are often hard to foresee,
latent conditions before an adverse event occurs. Understanding this leads to proactive rather than reactive risk management.

Historically, epidemiology has been concerned with infectious and deficiency diseases (such as tuberculosis
or rickets). However, safety professionals and epidemiologists have extended
theory to include occupational health and safety as well. The
helped it make the crossover from medicine to OSH&E.
complex occupational diseases and illnesses such as cancers, cluster illnesses

n the epidemiological incident causation model, hosts (workers), agents (hazardous conditions and behaviours), and environment (the workplace) interact to create incidents, just as hosts (people, animals, and plants) carry agents (infectious organisms) through an environment (the world) and spread disease. Using this model, investigators and researchers correlate various types of hosts, agents, and environments with various categories of incidents.

The purpose of epidemiological safety is to collect aggregate statistical data on incidents that have already occurred. The epidemiological model stresses prevention from precedent (preventing recurrences) rather than prevention of incidents, which may occur from existing hazards.

Describe the intent and the steps of an incident investigation.
